headline.main: The Noose Is Tightening For Smokers in New Jersey

docs.abstract: Noose tightens for smokers in New Jersey, as Legislature considers bill to ban smoking in restaurants, shopping malls and, if owner wishes, in leased office space; Princeton moves to ban smoking in bars as well; photos (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: John Burns sat at the bar at Triumph Brewing Company on Nassau Street, his Newport 100's and Bengal Gold pale ale forming a cozy universe along with his copy of ''The Turning Point'' by Malcolm Gladwell about crucial moments in social trends. ''It's a reading room,'' Mr. Burns, 45, said of the pub, across the street from the university's FitzRandolph Gate and populated last Sunday by a harmonious blend of tobacco lovers and others. ''It's a place where I can sit down and interact with a Nobel laureate or a guy who pumps gas.''
docs.snippet: John Burns sat at the bar at Triumph Brewing Company on Nassau Street, his Newport 100's and Bengal Gold pale ale forming a cozy universe along with his copy of ''The Turning Point'' by Malcolm Gladwell about crucial moments in social trends.   ...

headline.main: Princeton Considers Smoking Ban, but Taverns Vow to Fight

docs.abstract: Princeton, NJ, Borough and Township are expected to become first localities in New York metropolitan region to outlaw smoking in almost all public places, including bars and restaurants; tavern owners are expected to battle ban in court (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: It is all but certain that a local health panel will make Princeton Borough and Township the first localities in the New York metropolitan region to outlaw smoking in almost all public places, including bars and restaurants. But tavern owners are promising not to give up their smokers without a legal battle. After a public hearing on Tuesday night at which supporters of the ban cited the effects of secondhand smoke and opponents argued for personal freedom and the right to choose, the Princeton Regional Health Commission put off any action on the proposed law until its next meeting, on April 18. The 10-member panel voted unanimously last month to take up the proposal, which faces no opposition from its members.
docs.snippet: It is all but certain that a local health panel will make Princeton Borough and Township the first localities in the New York metropolitan region to outlaw smoking in almost all public places, including bars and restaurants. But tavern owners are...

headline.main: HIGH COURT HOLDS F.D.A. CAN'T IMPOSE RULES ON TOBACCO

docs.abstract: Supreme Court rules 5 to 4 that Food and Drug Administration has never received authority from Congress to regulate tobacco products, blow to Clinton administration's efforts to curb smoking; decision, rejecting rules proposed by agency in 1995 to restrict marketing of cigarettes to children, hands question of national tobacco regulation back to Congress; Justice Sandra Day O'Connor says in her majority opinion that FDA cannot regulate smoking despite health hazards; Justice Stephen G Breyer, in dissenting opinion, contends that FDA has authority over tobacco as public health matter; Breyer and O'Connor photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court today dealt a sharp blow to the Clinton administration's efforts to curb smoking, ruling 5 to 4 that the Food and Drug Administration had never received authority from Congress to regulate tobacco products. The decision, rejecting rules proposed by the agency in 1995 to restrict the marketing of cigarettes to children and teenagers, hands the question of national tobacco regulation back to Congress. An effort to confer jurisdiction on the Food and Drug Administration won some bipartisan support in Congress in 1998 but became mired in a broader debate over whether to give the cigarette industry immunity from damage suits.
docs.snippet: The Supreme Court today dealt a sharp blow to the Clinton administration's efforts to curb smoking, ruling 5 to 4 that the Food and Drug Administration had never received authority from Congress to regulate tobacco products.    The decision,...

headline.main: Excerpts From the Opinions on the Regulation of Tobacco by the F.D.A.

docs.abstract: Excerpts from Supreme Court's decision holding that Food and Drug Administration never received authority from Congress to regulate tobacco products (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today holding that the Food and Drug Administration had never received authority from Congress to regulate tobacco products. The vote in the case, Food and Drug Administration v. Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation was 5 to 4. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor wrote the majority opinion, and Justice Stephen G. Breyer wrote the dissent. FROM THE DECISION By Justice O'Connor This case involves one of the most troubling public health problems facing our nation today: the thousands of premature deaths that occur each year because of tobacco use. In 1996, the Food and Drug Administration, after having expressly disavowed any such authority since its inception, asserted jurisdiction to regulate tobacco products. The F.D.A. concluded that nicotine is a ''drug'' within the meaning of the Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act and that cigarettes and smokeless tobacco are ''combination products'' that deliver nicotine to the body.
